script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, let's jump into a mystery from Moses chapter 1 that's puzzled me for years. Moses has just beheld God's glory, seen the earth and its inhabitants, and God declares to him in verse 4, 'And thou art my son.' Then in verse 6, 'thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten; and mine Only Begotten is and shall be the Savior... wherefore, thou art a god.' But immediately, Satan shows up in verse 12 and says, 'Moses, son of man, worship me.' Why does Satan drop him from son of God to mere son of man right after that divine affirmation?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, that's the perfect hook to unlock our identity and purpose. Notice this pattern: God elevates Moses with his divine potential as a son of God, while Satan immediately drags him down to a mortal label, trying to make him forget who he really is. It's a battle over our true identity that starts right there in the vision.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Wait, a battle over identity? That's intriguing. So God sees us one way, Satan another?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. Look at Moses 1:4 and 6—God speaks directly to affirm Moses's worth and destiny. Then Satan in verse 12 calls him 'son of man' to counterfeit that truth, tempting him to worship as if he's just earthly, powerless.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Fascinating. How does Moses respond? Does he fall for it?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: No, watch what happens. In verses 13, 15, and 18, Moses declares back, 'I am a son of God,' remembering God's words. By verse 20-22, he commands Satan to depart in the name of the Only Begotten. It's powerful resistance through reclaimed identity.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's remarkable! So this sets up multiple perspectives on who we are—God's view versus Satan's counterfeit.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, from ancient times, God reveals our divine nature to His prophets. In Moses's day, it's personal revelation. But think about ancient Israel—they knew Moses as a deliverer, yet without this vision, they might have seen him more as a man. Today, through restoration, we see the full picture.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love that multi-perspective angle. Now, hold that thought—how does this pattern extend across dispensations?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Here's where it gets powerful. Fast forward to Abraham chapter 3, where Abraham sees our premortal existence. In verses 22-23, 'Now the Lord had shown unto me, Abraham, the intelligences that were organized before the world was; and among all these, there were many of the noble and great ones.' We were spirits before the world was!

script.speaker: David
script.text: Before the world was? That's mind-blowing. So our identity starts premortally?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. Verse 26 says, 'And they who keep their first estate shall be added upon... and they who keep not their first estate shall not have glory.' Notice this pattern: God organizes intelligences, chooses noble spirits like Abraham and us to come to earth and prove ourselves.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Proving ourselves—linking back to Moses's vision. Tell me more about that connection.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses 1:27-39, after resisting Satan, Moses asks in verse 30, 'Tell me... why these things are so?' God's answer in verse 39: 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' It's the purpose of creation, tied to our premortal choices in Abraham 3.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I never saw that pattern so clearly across these two chapters! From premortal council to Moses's earth vision.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And it echoes further. In Abraham 3:24-26, the Lord says to those spirits, 'We will prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.' That's our test now, just like Moses faced.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's profound. So the pattern of divine identity and proving continues. Any historical context to make this feel real?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. Consider the cultural insight in Moses 1:13-18—Satan tempts with counterfeits of God's power. Like an artificial plant looks real but isn't alive, Satan offers fake glory, saying in verse 13, 'There is no God.' But Moses recognizes the counterfeit because it lacks God's true power.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Counterfeits—that's a brilliant way to spot temptation. What else from history or culture?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses's time, Egyptian pharaohs claimed divine status, yet Satan tempts Moses similarly, but degraded. Archaeology shows ancient Near East views of gods demanding worship, mirroring Satan's tactic. But God's way elevates us as His children, not slaves.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Remarkable! That resolves the opening mystery—Satan attacked Moses's identity to derail his mission, but remembering 'I am a son of God' was the key.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes! Verse 25 shows the turning point: 'Depart hence, Satan,' Moses says, empowered by Christ's name. The mystery reveals Satan's strategy hasn't changed—he confuses our divine worth to tempt us.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Perfect resolution. Now, hidden connections most people miss?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: First, Moses 1:36—'tell me concerning this earth, and the inhabitants thereof, and also the heavens.' Abraham 3 answers it directly with premortal spirits and purpose. That's no coincidence; these visions frame the Creation.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Whoa, that's a connection I missed! What's another?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Notice in Abraham 3:22, intelligences 'organized before the world was.' Links to Moses 1:31-33 where God shows 'worlds without number'—our premortal identity spans all creations, part of the Plan of Salvation.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's transformative. One more?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: President Nelson echoes it: 'If the Lord were speaking to you directly, the first thing He would make sure you understand is your true identity.' Just like to Moses, contrasting Satan's confusion in verse 12.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Brilliant cross-reference. How does this apply today?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: President Nelson also said, 'The way you think about who you really are affects almost every decision you will ever make.' Knowing we're children of God from Abraham 3 changes how we resist temptations like Moses did.

script.speaker: David
script.text: So practical. In daily choices, we prove our first estate.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, and with Christ's help, we gain eternal life as in Moses 1:39. Modern prophets mirror this ancient pattern, urging us to prioritize our divine identity over worldly labels.

script.speaker: David
script.text: This changes how I read the Old Testament now—framed by these truths.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. One more link: Abraham 3:25-26 on keeping our first estate ties to resisting Satan in Moses 1:24-26, where the Lord helps Moses overcome.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Powerful. For our listeners, what's the takeaway?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Ponder Moses 1 and Abraham 3 this week. Look in the mirror and declare, 'I am a child of God,' like God told Moses. See how it shifts your view of challenges.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And list choices that flow from that identity, as President Nelson suggests. It'll transform your week.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. These chapters reveal who we are, why we're here, and God's work for us.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah, for these profound connections. Listeners, dive into Moses 1 and Abraham 3—your divine destiny awaits discovery.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Until next time, remember your premortal promise and resist the counterfeits.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's it for this episode. Come follow me in the scriptures.
